description:
The crash occurred at the T-intersection of an east/west two-lane secondary arterial road
                        and a north/south two-lane local road. The arterial curves to the south (left) as it approaches
                        the intersection from the east with a radius of curvature of 375m. Traffic counts indicate it
                        carries 9,036 vehicles per day with a posted speed limit of 72kmph (45mph). The local road is
                        straight and is controlled by a stop sign with a posted speed of 48kmph (30mph). Conditions were
                        daylight and dry on a weekday morning.


                        Vehicle #1 was a 1999 Ford F-250 pickup pulling a trailer loaded with four horses westbound on
                        the two lane arterial road. Vehicle #2, a 1999 Toyota Corolla, was southbound on the local road.
                        Vehicle #2 attempted to make a left turn to go east when its left side was struck by the front
                        of Vehicle #1. After impact the F-250 (V1) rotated counterclockwise and jackknifed with the
                        truck coming to rest partially off the south side of the intersection facing southeast. The
                        trailer remained on the road and came to rest facing southwest. The Corolla (V2) rotated
                        clockwise and came to rest just off the south side of the road facing southwest.


                        Vehicle #1 was driven by a 25-year-old female that was belted with no deployed airbags and not
                        injured in the crash. She stated that she began to decelerate as she approached because the
                        other vehicle appeared to be easing out into the intersection. However, she didn't believe the
                        Corolla (V2) would continue because of lack of gap distance. Once she realized Vehicle #2 was
                        beginning to turn she applied her brakes, honked the horn and steered to the left in an attempt
                        to avoid a collision.


                        The Critical Precrash Event for Vehicle #1 was other vehicle encroaching from crossing street
                        turning into opposite direction. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to
                        this vehicle. There were no associated factors for Vehicle #1.


                        Vehicle #2 was operated by a 46-year-old female that was belted with deployed frontal airbags.
                        She had minor injuries but was not transported for treatment. She indicated that she stopped at
                        the stop sign, looked both ways but didn't see Vehicle #2 approaching. She believes she may have
                        pulled out into the intersection slowly because of a reduced size spare tire present on the
                        right rear of the vehicle that made her uncomfortable.


                        The Critical Precrash Event for Vehicle #2 was this vehicle turning left at intersection. The
                        Critical Reason for the Critical Event was a recognition error, inadequate surveillance. An
                        Associated factor was an other driver related experience factor; she was uncomfortable with the
                        spare tire on the vehicle. She also wore corrective lenses for a farsighted condition.
